E.g.: a common strategy, for example, may be a group of farms grouped in a consortium to market their products under the same brand name.

Please note that their incorporation must be by means of a written deed registered by a notary public. However, the share capital that may be made available to the consortium or the consortium company can vary.

Unlike the consortium, the consortium company:

  • pursues the benefit of the participating enterprises;
  • may be incorporated as any of the other corporate forms (partnerships and limited liability companies), except as an ordinary partnership (società semplice) and provided that all the rules are compatible;
  • its main purpose is not the distribution of profits.

E.g.: the member companies of a consortium company may, for example, try to obtain better conditions for the supply of raw materials.

For further information on the legal status of consortia and consortium companies, please refer to Articles 2602 and those following and 2615-ter of the Italian Civil Code at the following link: www.altalex.com/index.php?idnot=36506.

body.value:
The cooperative is the form that allows you to make decisions in the most democratic way possible: this is because each member is entitled to only one vote, irrespective of the capital share she or he owns.

Please note that its incorporation must be made by means of a written deed registered by a notary public. However, the share capital that may be made available to the cooperative is variable.

Furthermore, a cooperative does not aim to distribute profits, but is intended to secure more favourable conditions for its members. Hence, it is said that the cooperative has a mutual aid purpose.

The cooperative must consist of at least nine partners. The minimum number may be reduced to three if:

  • the members are all individuals;
  • the charter provides for the adoption of the rules and regulations of limited liability companies.

The partners can be:

  • cooperators, who have joined the company to obtain more favourable conditions;
  • subsidizers, who contribute funds;
  • backers, who provide sources of external resources.

In addition, cooperatives enjoy tax facilitations. Remember that agricultural and fishing cooperatives, as well as employment and social cooperatives, enjoy a partial exemption from the IRES tax.

For further information on cooperatives, please refer to Articles 2511 and those following of the Italian Civil Code, full text available at the following link: www.altalex.com/index.php?idnot=36502.

For further information on how the Italian IRES tax works, please refer to the Guide to IRES.

The cooperative and consortium forms grant a number of advantages, because:

  • you can share your decisions on business activities with other partners;
  • with these forms, you can manage medium- and large-sized companies;
  • your liability and that of your partners is limited to the value of the company's share capital;
  • the economic and financial management can be controlled more easily;
  • cooperatives enjoy lower tax rates.

E.g.: suppose that the partners responsible for the XYZ cooperative possess, as part of their personal assets, property worth 300,000 euros, one vehicle worth 30,000 euros and that their company has debts amounting to 100,000 euros; the share owned by each partner amounts to 10,000 euros. If the company is unable to pay its debts, creditors may require payment by each member only up to the limits of their share value, i.e. 10,000 euros.

At the same time, cooperatives and consortia have some disadvantages:

  • they are expensive types of companies;
  • decisions mustbe made following special procedures;
  • they are required to draw up and submit a yearly balance sheet;
  • they must be managed using an ordinary accounting method;
  • they are incorporated by means of a written charter drawn up by a notary public.

In conclusion, this is an appropriate legal form if you and your partners wish to make high-risk medium to large investments. You can make small investments, but keep in mind that it is an expensive form in terms of administrative management.

items.title: Why choose a cooperative or a consortium: advantages and disadvantages

body.value:
If you and your partners have decided to start a company with other partners in the form of a cooperative or a consortium, you can carry on commercial activities. In this case, however, the most important decisions for your company need to be taken through special procedures and during dedicated meetings.

The cooperative form does not require a complex organizational setup. The consortium can be either:

  • a traditional consortium, or
  • a consortium company.

To begin activities, the following are required:

1. the VAT number to be registered at Inland Revenue;

2. registration in the Company Register (Registro delle Imprese);

3. registration with INPS (the National Social Security Institute);

4. registration with INAIL (National Institute of Insurance against Accidents at the Workplace), if required for your business.

5. For cooperatives, registration as a member of the register of cooperative companies (Albo delle Società Cooperative).

In addition, you can identify the cooperative or the consortium with a name, which will be the name of the company.

E.g.: possible names for a company in the form of a cooperative or a consortium could be: Viola coop a r.l., Consorzio Mari e Monti, and so on.

The cooperative and the consortium are special forms of enterprise.

The cooperative is a company in which the objectives, compared to normal market conditions, are to:

  • give its members the opportunity to purchase goods and services on the easiest terms possible;
  • pay a better salary to its members.

A consortium has as its objective to:

  • bring companies together to coordinate and promote joint business activities.

In both cases, the liability for the shares of the enterprise is limited to the amount paid up to the cooperative or consortium.

Starting a company as a cooperative or a consortium means:

  • working with others;
  • having a limited liability and risk for the actions undertaken while carrying out business activities;
  • making decisions that affect your company together with other partners;
  • carrying on commercial activities.
  • having no limits when planning business activities.
  • promoting joint actions together with other companies;
  • securing the best prices or the highest salaries to the members.

Quante leggi, regolamenti e procedure si sono accumulate nel tempo? Quante se ne aggiungono giorno dopo giorno?

Con la ferma convinzione che il rilancio economico della Sardegna passa soprattutto attraverso lo snellimento delle procedure e il riordino dell’apparato normativo che troppo spesso rappresentano degli ostacoli per chi vuole fare impresa, la Regione ha avviato diverse iniziative con un unico obiettivo: la semplificazione. 

Un tavolo regionale permanente per la semplificazione normativa e un nucleo tecnico vigilano e operano attivamente per ridurre i costi e gli oneri che gravano su cittadini e imprese a causa della burocrazia.

Un'azione di ascolto ma soprattutto di forte supporto per aiutare gli imprenditori di fronte ai repentini e continui mutamenti normativi e procedurali, strumenti semplici e di facile utilizzo, che migliorano il rapporto tra pubblica amministrazione, cittadini e imprese

Il tavolo regionale permanente per la semplificazione normativa è coordinato dal Presidente della Regione e con una partecipazione equilibrata di pubblico e privato. Ne fanno parte permanente Assessori, rappresentanti delle associazioni delle Autonomie locali, degli enti locali delle organizzazioni economiche sindacali.

Il Nucleo tecnico per la semplificazione delle norme e delle procedure, coordinato dal Direttore generale dell’Assessorato dell’Industria, di cui fanno parte dirigenti e funzionari delle strutture regionali coinvolte è incaricato di individuare le leggi superate, ed eventualmente “semplificabili”, e le sovrapposizioni di competenze.  Una continua certosina operazione di monitoraggio, di segnalazione e di riordino di tutto ciò che non funziona per disegnare un’amministrazione più semplice.

Il Coordinamento regionale Suap (gli Sportelli unici per le attività produttive) dell'Assessorato dell'Industria è il punto di riferimento del Nucleo tecnico per la semplificazione.

Combattere la burocrazia e camminare verso la semplificazione per migliorare l’Isola: oggi è possibile!

Sardegna+semplice, consultazione on line per la semplificazione burocratica.

 Presentazione del DDL sulla semplificazione: meno burocrazia più competitività.

Why should an entrepreneur be interested in investing in Sardinia?

Here are ten good reasons:

  1. Its strategic location in Italy and the Mediterranean, especially considering the new markets that are developing on the southern Mediterranean shore
  2. The excellent quality of life and a favourable climate
  3. The increasing demographic trend
  4. The dynamic productive fabric with good development prospects on international markets
  5. The presence of qualified and talented human capital in the emerging sectors of global economy
  6. The presence of universities closely linked to the economic and productive fabric, research centres, business incubators and technology clusters
  7. The valuable environmental and cultural assets
  8. The competitive infrastructure system for business localization
  9. A stable regional government, strongly oriented to economic development with good spending capabilities of national and European public funds
  10. The absence of organized crime

But the real reason for investing in Sardinia is that this island is a land of innovation.

As strongly oriented in the direction of the European 2020 strategy, Sardinia aims to invest in an intelligent specialization model based on high added-value sectors to encourage growth which are compatible with sustainable development, tourism, agribusiness, ICT, biotechnology and the green economy.

Regardless of the changing economic trends, in Sardinia you can find a productive, economic, social and institutional system, ready for and responsive to economic recovery and for future market opportunities. This is why a large part of the regional agenda calls for investments and policies to stimulate the growth of a dynamic and innovative entrepreneurial fabric capable of creating and enhancing workforce development in the area.

The Sardegna Ricerche Regional Science and Technology Park has been for years the place where companies, regional authorities and research models have been meeting; two public incubators work there, with a general scope of action and a specialist vocation. There is a Bioincubator in Pula (CA) for activities related to life sciences. While Alghero (SS) hosts a platform for Food Technology and Biotechnology applied to health and environment.

They are supported by the institutions to foster new technologies and industrial applications, supporting start-up companies, aspiring entrepreneurs, facilitate the processes of transformation of knowledge into economic activities. Incubators, while paying great attention to the social impact of promoted activities, generate a dynamic system where good ideas are transformed into  business, coping with the rooted weaknesses of the local start-up system (gap between research and business, lack of innovation services, absence of a market for technology transfer, venture capitals difficult to acquire at critical stages of business start-up activities, inability of traditional finance to provide appropriate and timely responses).

Sardinia can provide answers to these shortcomings, because there are places to support entrepreneurial vision, to ensure the possibility of success of initiatives through the provision of basic entrepreneurial elements: physical space, administrative services and organizational qualified personnel, fostering credibility to attract investments.

Therefore, Sardinia offers a protected environment where brilliant ideas may thrive in the collaboration of technology platforms and companies, fostering ideas and creativity, benefiting from the presence of private incubators which have deep knowlede of risk capital systems.

Within Sardegna Ricerche Science Park, you will find the knowledge and skills you need in high economic and social impact sectors, products, processes and services with high technological content.

The CRS4 facility in Pula (CA) work on enabling computational technologies and their application tor: biomedicine, biotechnology, genetics, bioinformatics, pharmacology, information society, energy and environment, chemical IT, energy efficiency, reducing greenhouse gases, imaging, digital content, interaction design, geoweb, mobile science, home automation, GIS, internet of things. Ateam of researchers and technical experts, a centre of high-performance computing (47 teraflops, and several petabytes of disk space), technological equipment including innovative software and hardware, cloud computing, virtual clusters, a laboratory for sequencing and genotyping, scientific equipment, cutting-edge computational platforms: these are some of its main assets.

Porto Conte Ricerche, based in Alghero (SS), focuses on food technologies, applications for food certification a biotechnologies applied to and the environment, the industry and health. Laboratories, specialized equipment and scientific and technological know-how, offer space for the development of technology platforms (food technology, nuclear magnetic resonance, analytical chemistry, nanobiotechnology, proteomics and immunoproteomics, plant processing), which are important tools for technological innovation, promote the enhancement of skills and the lab capabilities of institutions and businesses.

International projects and an interdisciplinary and multidisciplinary approach make these two science parks the heart of local research and an occasion for economic development.

In Sardinia, 8 industrial hubs are operational: Cagliari (south), Sulcis (southwest), Ogliastra (central east), Medio Capidano (central south), Oristano (central west), Nuoro (central), Sassari (north) and Olbia (north east). All industrial consortia have an experience of several years of hospitality for business initiatives of different size and type; they were designed and located in strategic positions, keeping in mind the location of ports, the main airports, the road and railway networks, their infrastructures provide services and sub-services guaranteeing competitiveness and operational capacity for any venture you plan to start.

They were build to cope with the infrastructural requirements of the industrial areas, they now serve as focal points for development. They were turned into regional hubs in 2008, offering premises and industrial services for the ordinary management of companies and internationalization purposes, support the implementation of trade agreements and assist companies in the use of cyclically available incentives put forward by the public administration for the innovation and development of the business sector.

By providing IT and technological-environmental platforms, integrated systems for waste management, coastal depots, power lines, wastewater treatment plants, water purification and transportation networks connected with the main inland network infrastructure, they carry out activities of public interest for large areas to support the economic development of the territories.

All provincial industrial consortia are well connected with local craftsmanship areas production sites which, almost on a municipal basis, offer additional premises and services.

Based on the features of your business idea, localization strategies are oriented towards analyses and the choice of markets, organizational, technological and internationalization options. Geographical factors and the characteristics of the locations chosen, socioeconomic services and environment, infrastructures and industrial facilities are all factors to be taken into account when making a decision.

The decision-making process, as well as financial incentives and dedicated regional policies, must also consider the different local assets: labour, management skills, transportation hubs, innovation rate, existing businesses and integration of supply chains. These are all assets that are found throughout the island to facilitate your localization process, in line with the competitiveness of the area that you choose as a destination.

The place where your concern will be developed is also influenced by personal perspectives, especially if you are about to set up a small enterprise or are a craftsperson, in addition to the variables of political stability, proximity to markets and supplies, research centres and where you can find skilled workers, if you wish to found a medium- or large-sized enterprise.

The Sardinian Regional Administration offers favourable conditions for the hosting of companies consisting of creating and supporting a network of industrial districts, areas for small businesses, infrastructure hubs, an ecosystem of innovation and research facilities, a combination of public incubators and private accelerators, measures for training and facilitations that periodically make the different territories attractive, particularly in the areas of crisis,. Sardinia is a friendly and safe system where you can start and develop your company.

items.title: Sardinia: the right place to start up a company

body.value:
As part of activities complementary to the primary and industrial sectors, Sardinia benefits from a functional network of providers of intangible services supporting traditional sectors and nurturing the system as a whole. In particular, the service industry in the fields of trade, transport and logistics is now the largest sector on the island, with more than 33,000 companies and 67% of the total number of employees.

Banking, insurance, and health care are major sectors; education, sports and cultural activities, as well as catering and rentals, enjoy high standards. Parallel to the tourist industry, noteworthy results have been achieved by farm holiday facilities, congress services, incentives (*) and conference-related activities in general. These are closely connected to and supported by travel agencies, tour operators and different categories of tourist guides.

The advanced tertiary sector is highly developed, because in Sardinia the ICT (especially in the new media area) and R&D (especially in the processes of innovation, biotechnology and genetics) communities are the largest category of consultancy and professional activities, covering the entire range of activities in support of existing or soon-to-be-established companies. The sector is achieving noteworthy results also in the e-commerce area.

An important role is being played by the tertiary, since Sardinia has always been one of Italy’s leading regions owing to the presence of cooperatives of all kinds and a very dynamic network of voluntary services.


(*) The companies achieving or exceeding the targets of production set, offer incentives  (travel bonuses) to their employees or travel agents.

In particular, the service industry in the fields of trade, transport and logistics is now the largest sector on the island, with more than 33,000 companies and 67% of the total number of employees.

Banking, insurance, and health care are major sectors; education, sports and cultural activities, as well as catering and rentals, enjoy high standards. Parallel to the tourist industry, noteworthy results have been achieved by farm holiday facilities, congress services, incentives (*) and conference-related activities in general. These are closely connected to and supported by travel agencies, tour operators and different categories of tourist guides.

The advanced tertiary sector is highly developed, because in Sardinia the ICT (especially in the new media area) and R&D (especially in the processes of innovation, biotechnology and genetics) communities are the largest category of consultancy and professional activities, covering the entire range of activities in support of existing or soon-to-be-established companies. The sector is achieving noteworthy results also in the e-commerce area.

An important role is being played by the tertiary, since Sardinia has always been one of Italy’s leading regions owing to the presence of cooperatives of all kinds and a very dynamic network of voluntary services.


(*) The companies achieving or exceeding the targets of production set, offer incentives  (travel bonuses) to their employees or travel agents.

Sardinia’s industrial origins were based on mining activities (coal, antimony, fluorite, barite, lead, silver, tin, copper), especially in the Sulcis, Medio Campidano and Sarrabus areas. Sardinian industrial production today has developed, with activities based on oil and petroleum products at Macchiareddu, Porto Torres, Portovesme, Ottana and Villacidro, with large refineries for the processing of crude oil, which have led to the development of specific industrial complexes, ranging from engineering to advanced metallurgy and oil platform production in the industrial area of Arbatax.

To date, the extraction, processing and sale of coke have played a vital role in the regional economy. The chemical-industrial sector has evolved and diversified over the years: from the manufacturing and processing of aluminium, also the green and blue economies (*) have developed.

Sardinia is one of Europe's regions with the most interesting geological heritage: its underground is rich in minerals, serving as the basis for the extraction industry, in particular stone quarrying, which had its prehistoric origins in the island’s obsidian deposits, and now there is the quarrying of marble in the district of Orosei and granite in the district of Gallura. In the north-east of the island, there is a strong cork district, with many local plantations.

During the years, several automotive and railway centres have developed in the industrial area of Villacidro and the shipbuilding sector has maintained a sound market share. To support the increasingly active construction sector, which now benefits from the new trend in green and sustainable building for the large refurbishing market, renewable energy has expanded during the last five years thanks to the abundance of natural renewable resources (wind and sun) in Sardinia. Although the textile sector is still present mostly at the home industry level, it is also true that the growing ICT sector in Cagliari will possibly pave the way to the development of this future infrastructure industry. Interesting dynamics have also developed in the waste processing chains connected to land reclamation and redevelopment projects.

 

(*) Green Economy means an economy whose environmental impact is kept sustainable.

Blue Economy is a development of the green economy that provides for CO2. zero emissions.

Both invest not only in protecting the environment but they are designed to make lower investments, create more jobs and achieve a higher revenues. They are based on the development of physical principles and the use of advanced scientific techniques.

Agribusiness, including fisheries and aquaculture (especially sea urchins, tuna fish, mussels, fish eggs and tasty local fish), plays a key role in the production system and maintenance of local species, in sustainable management of local traditions and the promotion of its products on an international scale.

Its strengths are: wine (rediscovered and re-evaluated native grape varieties, international varieties, major award-winning industry leaders), olives (typical local varieties and highly specialized companies), dairy products (with examples of excellence in the cheese industry), animal husbandry (meat and meat-based products having unique organoleptic properties), cereals (wheat and wheat varieties) and vegetables (e.g., tomatoes and artichokes).

The primary system has a deep cultural identity, is biologically linked with the environmental and culinary heritage and developed in all parts of the island. The ports and marsh systems, the good climate, DOP and IGP product labelling (40 among wines, cheeses, crops and livestock), which are derived from the non-clonability of genetic and local varieties, are the backbone of the regional primary sector.

All the specificity of the primary and secondary products, flavours and processing are organically tasty, thanks to the traditional use of lands, the sun, moisture and winds.

The production chain of the food industry, employing 37,000 people (92% agriculture, 3% fishing, aquaculture and forestry, 6% food processing), refers to both the primary sector and the manufacturing and processing sector. The areas available for growth are close at hand in this growing market, including exports.

The ancient skills handed down from generation to generation is at the heart of the Sardinian handicrafts system.

Simple, basic, elegant and colourful tapestries, gold and silver, coral, filigree, iron and other metals, carpets and embroidery, baskets, blankets, carved wood, cork mats, hides and skins, knives and cutting boards, stones and ceramics. These are just some of the many products of Sardinian folk art and tradition which have kept the island’s culture alive and flourishing, making it an independent sector that supports and promotes other productive sectors.

Raw wool, raw cotton and linen, wooden looms and spinning wheels, kits for wall hangings, curtains, pillows and towels, make weaving one of the most popular activities on the island. Other natural fibres (straw, raffia, wicker, asphodel, mastic tree, palm, rushes, reeds, etc..) used in the manufacture of baskets represent another large portion of handicraft products that are known and appreciated all over the world.

Floral designs, feminine grace, patience and skill, geometrically decorated buttons, crosses and rosaries, jewellery, gifts, clothing and footwear, furniture and ornaments, embroidery, dishes and kitchen utensils, shawls, chairs and pins: folk art creates original and unique products. The knives are true works of art that combine the mastery of the blacksmith’s art with that of the carving and engraving of horn handles.

Sardinian handicrafts are not only a productive activity, but a way of life that thrives inside the homes and accommodation facilities, an integral part of local tradition. Originally created to deal with practical issues, Sardinian handicrafts produce objects that are functional to modern life, intended for domestic trade and export.

An investment in this sector can focus on the integration of creativity and style, combining tradition and innovation, for the offering of technical advisory services and the establishment of competitive strategies.

Equally attractive for investments are also the non-artistic production chains, such as those related to the construction industry and the manufacturing and processing of agricultural products.

This sector includes 920 hotel facilities with 108,000 beds, 3115 non-hotel accommodation facilities with 98,000 beds, a well-established service and recreation network; it is based on Sardinia’s uniqueness of natural resources, coasts and islands, culture and crafts, culinary and human resources.

Although the trend confirms a specialization in the sea and beach segment, but the potential and opportunities offered by the land and its diversity are endless. The average of 2,000,000 tourists with a total of 11,000,000 overnight stays (60% Italian and 40% foreigners) confirms the role of the island as a popular place for vacations, relaxation, entertainment and related activities. The main tourist centres, rich with charming towns and villages, connected with a widespread network of farm holiday facilities, are located in the famous Costa Smeralda area, on the sunny Riviera del Corallo and the cozy Gulf of Orosei, not to mention the coast-to-mountain Ogliastra area, the Costa del Sud and the spectacular Costa Verde. The high concentration of hotels in these areas has not curbed tourists' enthusiasm for the discovery of the interior, thanks to the increased level of accessibility of the environmental, cultural and local food heritage, focusing on the promotion of local activities and traditions. All the many different offers for tourists show that the area is open to new initiatives, including cultural, natural, recreational, sports, conference and wellness-related activities, not to mention theoveragesector (tourism for the elderly), and the educational and yachting sectors.

Importantly, the impact that the growing rural tourism sector can have on the economy of the island may also be enhanced thanks to the many opportunities offered by its mountains and hills, the water body system and, of course, opportunities for trekking. Companies in the tourism sector continue to invest in Sardinia.

Sardinia has an economic system consisting of a number of manufacturing companies organized according to a district model: they are located in specific areas where the supply chain is specialised. The knowledge system is often based on local knowledge, but with an innovative approach to both processes and products. The collaborative relationships among firms are mostly of an informal kind, typical of the district model.

Such an organization allows opening up to external markets and thus being more competitive on the international market.

The industrial district model created in Sardinia in the 1990s has now evolved and has been institutionalized in local production systems.

The Local Production Systems (SPLs) of Sardinia are referred to as homogeneous productive contexts characterized by a high concentration of industrial enterprises, mainly small and medium-sized, and a special internal organization. Sardinian SPLs operate in the sectors of advanced logistics, information technology and communications, marine, agribusiness and health-care biotechnology.

The Industrial Districts (DIs) are local production systems which, in addition to being characterized by a concentration of enterprises, also show a productive specialization of company systems. DI sectors are: stone quarrying in the provinces Ogliastra, Nuoro and Olbia-Tempio, cork in Calangianus and Tempio Pausania, fashion and textiles in the provinces of Oristano, Nuoro and Ogliastra.

items.title: The industrial districts and the local production systems

body.value:
Sardinia is a land with a simple and cooperative real economy. Its structured production fabric is based on tourism, agribusiness, handicrafts and advanced services, but  it has not neglected traditional industrial processes.

The island offers a model of development that has led to expansion of its consolidated levels of excellence, focusing on the technological tertiary sector and green and blue economy(*) , life sciences and the primary sector. The sequence of levels of the tertiary sector, from trade to tourism and logistics, the industrial sector (mining, manufacturing, power generation, etc.), the construction sector and, finally, agriculture, show the production chains in which a business can find its space for development.

The coasts, the environment, culture, art, wine and food traditions support the tourist industry, which also favours the development of precision craftsmanship (manual ability and creativity backed by advanced technologies),are now present and recognized on international markets.

The tradition of high quality in the primary sector supports agribusiness. The creativity and the industrious talent of the business world, combined with the strength of the specialization of human capital, support all sectors of traditional industry, thanks to skill in the use of raw materials. Logistics and advanced services and processes, compliance with environmental sustainability standards and ICT are the agents that link together the entire production system which, by withstanding the fluctuation of economic trends, is able to enhance its territorial vocations. With a small margin of approximation, the fabric consists of 168,000 enterprises, 35,000 of which operate in agriculture, 13,000 in industry, 24,000 in building, 43,000 in trade, 41,000 in the tertiary sector and 11,000 are not classified. There are 8,500 foreign companies, 40,000 businesses owned by women, 17,000 young entrepreneurs and a workforce of 600,000: this overview of the Sardinian production system expresses vitality, resilience and an opening to new worlds and to all who wish to work here.


(*)  Green Economy means an economy whose environmental impact is kept sustainable.

Blue Economy is a development of the green economy that aims to arrive at zero CO2 emissions. Both invest not only in protecting the environment but are designed to lower investments, create more jobs and achieve a higher profits. They are based on the development of physical principles and the use of advanced scientific techniques.

Social infrastructures are divided into health facilities, educational facilities, cultural and recreational facilities.

Health facilities

Medical care is provided through facilities of different types, accredited by the public and private sectors, offering hospitalization, health care and prevention activities. Public or accredited hospitals in Sardinia are divided into:

  • 1 hospital centre
  • 29 hospitals (direct management)
  • 2 hospitals integrated with the Universities of Cagliari and Sassari
  • 1 research institution
  • 12 accredited nursing homes, private premises providing health care services under a general public agreement

The Single Booking Centre is implemented in almost all 8 ASL health centres of Sardinia (http://www.sardegnasociale.it/index.php?xsl=348&s=11&v=9&c=3969&esp=1 ).

The ASL also serves as a reference point for the medical facilities and care homes affiliated with the National Health Service

The updated list was published on February 2013.

A complete map of all the social and health care facilities of Sardinia is available on SardegnaSalute (http://www.sardegnasalute.it/).

It is an active and responsive network of regional cooperation in support of social inclusion and the recovery of underprivileged people.

The SSM service in 2009 had an availability of slightly more than 202,000 beds in Italy, 5,781 of which were in Sardinia, and a further 48,000 beds in accredited facilities, 1,465 of which in Sardinia. The number of beds in public and private accredited facilities compared to the size of the population is 3.5 in Sardinia, if the total number of beds are taken into account (Day Hospital, Day Surgery, ordinary hospitalization, paid health services), while in Italy the value is 3.4.

Cultural and recreational facilities

Sardinian infrastructures for cultural services, on which public cultural investment projects have been based, include Libraries (http://www.sardegnabiblioteche.it/) which are the most common infrastructures (more than 90% of Sardinian municipalities have one), able to manage innovative services and organize as a thematic network, already active and efficient, not only in the sharing of good practices and tools, but also technologies and connectivity.

This system is enhanced by the widespread availability of cultural facilities, such as cinemas, museums, theatres and cultural spaces dedicated to different types of users. The management is mostly local and seems to be also fairly profitable.

With the purpose of supporting the implementation and management of various ICT systems, the Region of Sardinia has made significant investments in cutting-edge technological infrastructures.

ICT infrastructures include:

  1. the ICT connectivity network of the Public Administration
  2. the public access ICT connectivity network providing internet connections and on-line services

 The Autonomous Region of Sardinia has a Regional ICT Network (RTR), designed to meet the connectivity requirements of the Regional Administration, its institutions, and the companies connected to the regional health service.  Its construction started in 2005 and includes a fibre optic backbone that runs for about 1300 km throughout the region and provides a closed-loop connection to nine access points, one in each provincial capital city, to the public-access internet networks of the main cities (Cagliari, Sassari, Tempio Pausania and Lanusei) and the surrounding areas.

In the future, thanks to the enhancement of the RTR, the services will be provided to the Public Administration of Sardinia as a whole; progressively increasing infrastructure investments will ensure reliable and efficient services, reducing operating costs and scale economies.

The Region is committed into the development of ICT applications both to enhance the quality of the services provided by public administration and the infrastructure opportunities for new companies. It aims to cover all territories, also through public co-financing on the infrastructures which the private sector may not be able to provide.

The connectivity system, extended to industrial centres, research centres, enterprises, ASLs, etc., is intended to promote Sardinia as a "system" and, therefore, its competitiveness and development policies. The promotion of ICT to enhance competitiveness and productivity, has the strategic objective to steer the system towards business investment in the fields of high-tech and the innovation of products and processes, for the creation of intangible infrastructure and digital services.

Regarding the industry of digital convergence, regional policies aim to increase the companies' ability to use and access infrastructural assets and services, and develop parallel digital content, applications and services.

On December 31st, 2009, the regional power grid consisted of 10,694 km of 380 kV lines and 11,350 km of 220 kv lines (Source: Direzione regionale della Programmazione Unitaria e della Statistica Regionale).

The Region of Sardinia aims to ensure:

  • the stability and security of the network through a considerable strengthening of energy infrastructures,
  • the adjustment of the energy system to make it functional to the regional production system,
  • the diversification of energy sources to ensure efficient provision,
  • decreasing dependence on oil products, ensuring the compatibility of energy-related actions with environmental protection and the harmonization of the power grid infrastructures.

The current distribution and electricity transmission network is interconnected to the National Grid by the following infrastructure:

  • a submarine cable connecting Sardinia, Corsica and the rest of Italy (SACOI), its potential being 250 MW;
  • a submarine cable connecting Sardinia and Corsica (Sarco), its potential being 50 MW;
  • a submarine cable (SAPEI), its potential being 1,000 MW.

As far as renewable energy sources are concerned, Terna SpA data show that between 2000 and 2010, in Sardinia, the percentage of energy produced from renewable energy sources share increased from 1.5% to 15.5%. Over a total of 14,705 FER systems installed on the regional territory until 2011, 99% of them included solar energy (photovoltaic and thermal) facilities, 39 wind power plants, 19 water facilities, 18 bioenergy plants. There is no geothermal system.

The topic of new technologies applied to sustainability in the energy sector is being developing by universities and public research centres.

Due to insularity, wind force and the average annual temperatures, Sardinia's conditions may be favourable for a more efficient use of Renewable Energy Sources.

  • the diversification of energy sources to ensure efficient provision,
  • decreasing dependence on oil products, ensuring the compatibility of energy-related actions with environmental protection and the harmonization of the power grid infrastructures.

The current distribution and electricity transmission network is interconnected to the National Grid by the following infrastructure:

  • a submarine cable connecting Sardinia, Corsica and the rest of Italy (SACOI), its potential being 250 MW;
  • a submarine cable connecting Sardinia and Corsica (Sarco), its potential being 50 MW;
  • a submarine cable (SAPEI), its potential being 1,000 MW.

As far as renewable energy sources are concerned, Terna SpA data show that between 2000 and 2010, in Sardinia, the percentage of energy produced from renewable energy sources share increased from 1.5% to 15.5%. Over a total of 14,705 FER systems installed on the regional territory until 2011, 99% of them included solar energy (photovoltaic and thermal) facilities, 39 wind power plants, 19 water facilities, 18 bioenergy plants. There is no geothermal system.

The topic of new technologies applied to sustainability in the energy sector is being developing by universities and public research centres.

Due to insularity, wind force and the average annual temperatures, Sardinia's conditions may be favourable for a more efficient use of Renewable Energy Sources.

The total length of Sardinian water distribution system is about 4,941 Km. The total length of inland water distribution networks is 8,513 km; it provides a coverage equal to 91% of the population.

The infrastructures used for water production and distribution from surface basins for multiple uses (MSF) in the whole Region include: 47 dams, 21 stringers, 87 tanks and dividers, 37 lifting plants and distribution facilities for a total length of 957.78 km, 697.87 km of which include pipelines, 145.68 km canals and 114, 23 km tunnels. As for the civil infrastructure system, the Integrated Water Service, in terms of service potential, the level of coverage of the aqueduct service is satisfactory, with a value equal to 98% compared to a national average of 96%.

The total length of the sewage system is 7.225 km. The sewage treatment plant consists of 570 purification plants for indoor use, both residential and industrial.

In Sardinia, the average annual goods import and export by road is equal to 16.3 tons per capita.

The trade of goods by sea is clearly more consistent (648.9 tons per capita) and much higher than the national figure. Along with Calabria and Sicily, it accounts for nearly half of the national freight coasting trade.

Similarly, with regard to the air traffic, the number of passengers per 100 inhabitants is greater in Sardinia than the rest of Italy.

The three main airports of Sardinia (Cagliari, Olbia and Alghero) are located in the north and the south of the region, therefore the least accessible area is the central one, which coincides with the provinces of Oristano, Nuoro and Ogliastra. In particular, the Ogliastra area has an average travel time to reach the nearest airport <2 hours.

As far as rail freight traffic is concerned, accessibility to the railway stations providing cargo transport on railway cars is high in almost all of Sardinia.

The "Surveys aimed at analyzing the territorial and economic analysis of the demand for freight transport in Sardinia" study (http://www.sardegnamobilita.it/documenti/33_252_20091014141541.pdf) has recently been published, making it possible to analyze the geography of the production system and the Sardinian dynamics of the mobility of goods. The study focused on the inbound and outbound mobility of goods on the island through the carrying out of interviews to drivers at ports and telephone interviews with a sample of firms producing goods, integrated with an automatic calculation of the commercial vehicles driving on the main roads.

items.title: The mobility and circulation of goods and people

body.value:
Thanks to its central position in the Mediterranean, the current regional policies in the field of air transport aim at a strong interconnection within the island and with the airports outside the island.

The Sardinian airport system enjoys a consolidated structure, able to deal with the development of air traffic in the next decade. The current available capacity can meet a 10 million passenger traffic.

Altogether, there are 5 airport facilities (http://www.sardegnamobilita.it/index.php?xsl=1053&s=33&v=9&c=6674&es=6603&na=1&n=100) located throughout the region:

  • Cagliari-Elmas Airport
  • Airport of Olbia-Costa Smeralda
  • Alghero Airport
  • Oristano-Fenosu Airport
  • Tortoli-Arbatax Airport

As far as internationalization is concerned, the promotional policy of the airports has prompted a significant development of a network of connections between Sardinia and the rest of Europe, especially with low cost companies. 

In terms of domestic connections, the continuità territoriale initiative(http://www.sardegnamobilita.it/index.php?xsl=1058&s=33&v=9&c=6673&es=6603&na=1&n=100&esp=1) provides the opportunity for all citizens to move to national or EU destinations with equal opportunities, accessing a service that guarantees fair economic and quality conditions.

The port system of Sardinian is a key element to ensure territorial continuity, since almost all trade to and from the Island is carried out by sea. Sardinia enjoys 11 large/medium-sized port infrastructures (http://www.sardegnamobilita.it/index.php?xsl=1053&s=33&v=9&c=6667&es=6603&na=1&n=100) which are divided into different docking centres which include a number of ports of different profile:

  • the Cagliari centre has an international economic importance:
    • commercial port (passengers and partially freights and bulk carriers) (Port of Cagliari)
    • industrial port (Porto Canale) rapidly developing into a container handling facility with a transhipment service
    • industrial terminals of Assemini and Porto Foxi (the latter including two oil terminals, one managed by Saras SpA and the other by Enichem)
    • the Arbatax hub: commercial and industrial port of Arbatax-Tortoli
    • the Olbia centre has an international economic importance:
      • commercial and industrial port of Olbia
      • commercial port and rail terminal in Golfo Aranci
      • the Porto Torres hub, of international economic importance:
        • commercial and industrial port, serving the surrounding area and, in particular, the refineries located nearby the port
        • the north-east hub, regional and interregional economic significance:
          • ports of Palau, La Maddalena and Santa Teresa di Gallura
          • the Sulcis-Iglesias hub:
            • the ports of Portovesme, Calasetta and Carloforte,
            • the port of Sant 'Antioco, national economic significance, dedicated to the handling of goods and pleasure boating.

The regional port system also benefits from the presence of the Oristano-Santa Giusta hub, of national economic importance, located on the western coast of the island, used for the solo purpose of handling goods (mainly dry and liquid bulk).

in addition to the large infrastructure hubs for passengers and/or goods, about a hundred marinas are available, such as Porto Cervo (700 berths), one of the best-equipped of the island, Villasimius (750 berths), Alghero (500) and La Caletta-Siniscola (source: SardegnaMobilità).

 

Ports and marinas in Sardinia

The railway network runs for about 1.035 km, it is not electrified and only 4% is double-tracked.

Railway activities on the island are currently the responsibility of two companies:

  • the Ferrovie dello Stato Group operates, through the RFI and Trenitalia SpA subsidiaries, the 4 standard gauge railway lines which are included in the main Sardinian network
  • ARST S.p.A. (http://www.arst.sardegna.it/index.html) manages the remaining 5 active sections of the public transport system, all of them are narrow-gauge and are part of the secondary network, running for 205 km. The latter company also controls 404 km of tourist lines, narrow-gauge, active especially in the summer season and on-demand.

The railway network of Sardinia

The road network runs for approximately 8,454 Km. It consists of 3,002 km of national roads, 5,452 km of provincial roads (3,981 km are local municipal suburban roads).

The basic road network includes:

  • S.S.131 Carlo Felice, Cagliari, Sanluri, Oristano, Sassari and Porto Torres;
  • S.S.130, S.P .85 and S.P .2, Cagliari-Decimo-Iglesias-Carbonia;
  • S.S.131 DCN Oristano-Abbasanta, Nuoro, Olbia;
  • S.S.291 Nuova Sassari-Alghero;
  • S.S.597 and S.S.199 Sassari, Olbia and connection to Golfo Aranci;
  • S.S.125, S.S.133 and S.S.133bis (60.8 km): Olbia (the SP16 Golfo Aranci linkroad)-Arzachena-Palau-Santa Teresa di Gallura
  • S.S.125 Cagliari-Tortolì-Arbatax;
  • S.S.389/198 Tortolì-Lanusei-Nuoro;

S.S. 195 - Dorsale Casic - New ring road outside of Cagliari.

 

The enhancement of intermodality throughout the island and the integration between the various systems of rail, bus and car systems, are also worth mentioning. The strengthening oft he interchange nodes is carried out thanks to the exchange hubs, which also connect lines belonging to the same service. Additional services are also provided to users (comfortable services, information desks, etc.). SardegnaMobilità (http://www.sardegnamobilita.it/index.php?xsl=1058&s=33&v=9&c=6649&es=6603&na=1&n=100&esp=1) also provides a list of first level and second level hubs, and the new intermodal centres funded by the Region.

The regional transport system plays an important and strategic role in the local economic, social and environmental development policies in Sardinia: internationalization, the development of insularity, the solution of isolation-related issues in the centre of the island, widespread accessibility, sustainable mobility in urban areas and in areas with high concentration of tourists. The Region is directly responsible for the planning and the operational and financial management of the actions aimed at upgrading and modernize the transport system in an integrated manner.

This is the right way to change the concept of insularity-insulation, making it a strength that, through flight and sea connections, may support Sardinia with major economic  and production.related impacts, meeting the demand at national , Mediterranean, European levels.

Further information on transport infrastructures and regional mobility may be found on SardegnaMobilità. (http://www.sardegnamobilita.it/index.html)

T website also gives access to the Travel Planner service (http://www.sardegnamobilita.it/index.php?xsl=1032&s=33&v=9&c=6756&nodesc=1) that may be used to plan trips with public transports: by entering the place of origin and the destination, the date and time, you will be provided with the various travel solutions and the details of available services.

 In addition, the Regional Observatory on transport infrastructures and logistics (http://www.unioncameresardegna.it/index.asp) is the information system that Unioncamere Sardegna uses to monitor the planning, implementation and development of networks and infrastructure nodes in the service sector, for both enterprises and private citizens. The joint regional infrastructure system is able to verify, analyze and periodically compare the progress of development.

Sardinia enjoys a strategic position at the heart of the Mediterranean Basin. Its location, combined with the currently available infrastructural facilities, may generate several competitive advantages connected to the central position of the Mediterranean markets and to its international relations, in particular between Europe and the North African shore.

Moreover, its natural insularity is gradually being coped with through territorial continuity policies, which are essential for economic and social development and for the reinforcement of external relations.

Sardinia is a natural hub.

In Sardinia there is a common cultural heritage, often integrated with important landscape areas. There are several cultural institutions and facilities (654 libraries and 203 museums), as well as sites of archaeological interest (60), architectural heritage centres and monuments (733), 1 UNESCO site, works of art, events and festivals throughout the region. The integration of cultural heritage with natural resources and landscape, along with the strengthening of trends towards forms of entertainment based on the enjoyment of environmental, cultural and landscape resources, is an important competitive advantage.

In addition to the cultural heritage connected to tangible assets, Sardinia enjoys a large intellectual heritage of artists, designers, sculptors, painters, writers, internationally renown maître à penser.

For some time now, the Region of Sardinia has allocated funds and developed strategies to safeguard its historical and artistic heritage through the restoration of monuments, churches, theatres and sculptures, city centres, urban facilities and buildings. Sardinia was the first Italian region to implement the provisions of the "Code of Cultural and Landscape Heritage" by issuing the Regional Landscape Plan Instrument for the purpose of managing the local territory and defend, develop and foster the historical, cultural and urban identity of the territory, thus protecting its cultural and natural landscape.

Much is being done to improve development policies which aim at encouraging the integration of public and private actions for the creation of new business opportunities. The Region of Sardinia encourages the promotion of the values ​​of identity and tradition through the dissemination of knowledge on Sardinian culture with a dedicated portal, Sardegna Cultura

The territory of Sardinia is rich in natural resources characterized by a multitude of environments and landscapes, a great number of species (animals and plants) and natural ecosystems and habitats. Much of this heritage is now part of a system of protected natural land and sea parks, and sites of EU concern, also known as the Regional Ecological Network

(http://www.sardegnaambiente.it/foreste/documentazione/cartografia/rete_ecologica.html). The network, with a total area of ​​approximately 590,083 hectares, consists of several protected areas:

  • 5 Parks including 3 National Parks (Archipelago of La Maddalena, Gulf of Orosei and Gennargentu, Asinara island) and 2 Regional Natural Parks (Molentargius-Saline and Porto Conte)
  • 5 Marine Protected Areas (Sinis Peninsula - Island of Mal di Ventre, Tavolara - Punta Coda Cavallo, Capo Carbonara, Asinara Island and Capo Caccia-Isola Piana)
  • 20 natural monuments

In addition to them, 107 sites of EU concern  (about 20% of the region) are also to be taken into account, 92 of which are animal and plant protection areas (Sites of Community Importance) and 15 are birds protection areas (Special Protection Areas).

This heritage plays a strategic role from a development policy point of view, fostered by the Region of Sardinia during the last years. The competitive advantage is the ability of these resources, if properly protected and enhanced, to support recreational and cultural services and economic activities functional to the economic development of the territories and to the improving of the quality of life of local populations.

The island enjoys a Mediterranean climate with mild and relatively rainy winters and dry and warm summers. The climate is influenced by the sea. Its effects tend to fade as you move towards the centre of the island. The annual average temperature is between 11°C in the inland areas and 17°C on coastal areas, with minimum values ​​in January and February and maximum values ​​during the months of July and August.

Rainfalls are almost null during the summer, and in winter they reach their maximum values after the heavy autumn rains. The region is very much exposed to winds and the entire coast is influenced by the so-called sea breezes (brezze marine).

The most common wind is the wind that comes from the north-west. Other recurring winds are the tramontana, the levante, the ponente, and the sirocco blowing from the south-east.

The workforce   and human capital  are key factors for an enterprise.

Human resources determine the success of a company depending on how they are managed: they are as important as the organization, the management, the quality of products and the technology employed by a company.

To be competitive and efficient, a company must find qualified human resources, consistent with its missionand corporatebusiness. For this reason, you will certainly want to invest in a skilled workforce.

Therefore, choose the best professionals in the area and get acquainted with local dynamics.

The presence of two deeply-rooted academic institutions, the universities of Cagliari and Sassari, thanks to the constant work of their departments in the fields of research and education, play an important role together with the network of high schools, technical education systems and regional public and private networks providing training services.

This system provides a lifelong learning system that meets the professional needs of local companies. On the island, you can find all the skills, professionalism and craftsmanship that your activities may need.

When entrepreneurs choose a location for their companies, "geographic" factors tend to play a minor role, while other elements seem to be more strategic, including the presence of an adequate work pool, both in terms of quantity and quality, the availability of service facilities supporting company productivity and the presence of good infrastructures.

These are the factors available to companies in Sardinia; they provide the groundwork for developing competitive skills to work on the global market and have a competitive advantage over other territories in making an investment feasible. Sardinia offers an inclusive labour market, qualified human resources oriented to business needs, a system of transport infrastructures to guarantee accessibility, the mobility of goods and people and the presence of efficient utilities (energy, water resources and IT networks). In addition, a strong commitment to the protection and enhancement of the cultural and environmental heritage, regarded as an economic resource for the island, is capable of generating income and employment.

body.value:
In 2012, Sardinia had a total of 168,808 registered companies (Source: Infocamere).

Most of the companies worked in trade and the primary sector (agriculture and fisheries), followed by the construction and industrial sectors.

Among the services, the highest concentration of companies was found in the accommodation and food sectors, a 2.2% increase over the previous year. Sole proprietorships represented 66%, 15% were joint-stock companies and 16% were partnerships. A remaining 3% were cooperatives, limited partnerships and other legal forms.

The entrepreneurial density is approximately 10 companies per 1,000 inhabitants.

In 2012, the stillbirth rate (the ratio between the number of companies that were set up and those that shut down registered during the period of time and the stock capital of the registered companies at the beginning of the period of reference) was -0.5% (-1% in 2011).

Twenty-four percent of companies in Sardinia were registered as small businesses. They mostly belonged to the manufacturing and construction sectors. But even in trade, logistics, tourist services and catering sectors, the importance of small businesses is high.

Female entrepreneurship accounts for 24% of the regional entrepreneurial volume (about 40,000 enterprises), particularly in the service sector (65% of businesses owned by women). However, the phenomenon decreased between 2011 and 2012 (-0.84%). About half of them are sole proprietorships, 12% are limited companies.

Youth entrepreneurship (entrepreneurs below the age of 35) is less common than female entrepreneurship: only 10% of incorporated companies, with a total of 17,347 employees, and equally distributed over all productive sectors. This phenomenon has decreased by 7% among registered companies.

Foreign companies amount to 8,517 and have increased by 6%, being limited to the trade sector and with a high number of sole proprietorships.

ASIA data show that for the year 2010 the number of local company employees amounted to 368,106, of whom 43,994 in the sole manufacturing sector. The average number is 3.1 employees per firm. The business system therefore consists of a majority of small and very small enterprises specialized in traditional sectors; nonetheless, if properly stimulated in terms of innovation and internationalization, they may prove to be good opportunities for the entire regional economy.

According to the latest ISTAT Census of Population, carried out in 2011, 1,642,528 people live in Sardinia, a 0.7% increase compared to 2001.

The demographic trend is increasing, thanks to the consistently positive values of immigration, which shows that the island maintains its attractiveness for new residents, who are primarily foreign immigrants: between 2003 and 2010, the percentage of foreign immigration was 70%, compared to the 119% reduction in domestic immigration.

There were 40,174 foreign citizens in 2011 (2.4% of the entire resident population) and, according to ISTAT forecasts, by 2050, the numbers will increase by an average of 3.5% per year and also successful citizenship applications will increase by 2.2%.

The demographic structure is characterized by a higher concentration of women in their middle ages, especially as far as the working age population is concerned.

On a land that is often studied for its high rate of longevity, the average age of the population is 44 years; the numbers of the elderly are increasing, while the trend of the dependency ratio remains low, thus showing the burden of the elderly on the active population.

body.value:
Despite its structural weaknesses, Sardinia’s economic system can keep up with other regional economies.

Among the southern Italian regions, Sardinia has been included in the "Obiettivo Competitività" project and shows a good spending capacity of Structural Funds.

The island in figures:

  • The Gross Domestic Product in 2011 amounted to 29,900,000,000 euros in real terms (2.1% of the Italian GDP). Compared to the previous year, it had increased by 0.08%.
  • In 2011, the personal consumption expenditure was 19,700,000,000 euros with a 0.5% decrease compared to 2010.
  • The value of the investments was 6,000,000,000 euros, 8% of the value of the investments in the South of Italy and 2% of the total national investment.
  • The added value: 27,200,000,000 euros, 3.6% of which was produced by the primary sector (agriculture and fisheries), 10.5% by industry, 6.2% by the construction sector and the remaining 78.6% by services.
  • The value of exports in 2012: about 6,400,000,000 euros (+22% compared to 2011).

 The forecasts show a recovery of nearly two and a half points of national GDP (-0.8%) in 2013. Domestic demand will decrease by 1.3%, due to a reduction in consumption and investments.

The first signs of recovery should arrive in 2014, when the GDP is expected to grow by 0.6% thanks to the contribution of the two items of domestic demand (0.2% for consumption and 1.6% for investments), the increase of exports (3.3%) and a minor decrease of imports (-0.9%).

body.value:
If your choice falls on a limited partnership with share capital, you and your associates will have the opportunity to decide who among you wishes to take care of corporate management and who wishes to be a partner without assuming the risks and liabilities of business decisions.

In a limited partnership with share capital, partners are divided into limited partners and unlimited partners: this means that only the unlimited partners can make decisions concerning the company’s activities.

Furthermore, all unlimited members have unlimited joint and several liability while the limited partners participate only economically by providing the company with funds.

E.g.: a limited partnership with share capital includes two partners: Verde and Rosso. Verde has a 60,000 euro share and is an unlimited partner; Rosso has a 60,000 euro share and is a limited partner. If the company has debts amounting to 100,000 euros, Rosso may be required to pay the debt only up to 60,000 euros.

Just like the joint-stock company, to set up this kind of partnership a written company charter must be prepared and an initial share capital of 120,000 euros, divided into shares, must be paid up.

For further information on limited companies with share capital, please refer to the link www.altalex.com/index.php?idnot=37057 which includes Articles 2452 and those following of the Italian Civil Code.

items.title: The limited partnership with share capital

body.value:
The most complex form of enterprise is the joint-stock company.

Its incorporation must be made in written form and registered by a notary public. In addition, when the company is set up, paid up share capital of at least 120,000 euros is mandatory and the capital must be divided into shares.

Together with your partners, you can also choose to pay up only 25% of the share capital, at least at an initial stage.

You can set up a joint-stock company also on your own: this form is called a one-man joint-stock company. Your liability remains limited to the value of your share capital. Nonetheless, remember that in this case the initial capital of 120,000 euros must be fully paidup fromthe very beginning.

Finally, do not forget that your liability becomes unlimited if your company fails to regularly settleits debts when due, you have not paid up the share capital and you have not followed the proper procedures in notifying its incorporation or its transformation into a one-man joint-stock company.

For further information on how a joint-stock company works, please refer to Articles 2325 and the following ones of the Italian Civil Code at the following link: www.altalex.com/index.php?idnot=37056.

Together with the low-capital limited liability company, in 2012 another new form of enterprise was added: the simplified limited liability company (ssrl).

This new corporate form is provided for in Article 2463bis of the Italian Civil Code, available at the following link: www.altalex.com/index.php?idnot=37058.

Compared to traditional LLCs, partners must be below the age of 35 at the time of its incorporation.

Just like traditional LLCs, your company must be set up by means of a written deed registered by a notary public. Liability of the partners is still limited to the value of the share capital and the partners of an LLC must always be physical persons, never companies.

Just like low-capital limited liability companies, a significant advantage is that you can pay up 1 euro only as share capital for its incorporation.

At the same time, however, banks may require important sureties before granting a loan. This is due to the fact that the company can be incorporated with a very low initial share capital.

body.value:
La società di capitali ti dà la possibilità di fare impresa con diversi vantaggi, perché:

  • puoi condividere le decisioni sull’attività con altri soci;
  • con questa forma, puoi gestire aziende di medie e grandi dimensioni;
  • la tua responsabilità e quella dei tuoi soci è limitata alla quota messa a disposizione nel capitale sociale società;
  • la gestione economica e finanziaria è più controllabile;
  • se gli utili sono elevati, sussiste una buona convenienza fiscale.

Esempio: supponiamo che i soci responsabili della società a responsabilità limitata Rosso e Nero srl posseggano nel proprio patrimonio personale un immobile del valore di 200.000 euro, titoli valutati 80.000 euro, due autovetture del valore di 50.000 euro e che la loro impresa abbia debiti per 50.000 euro; la quota di ogni socio è di 2.000 euro. Se la società non riuscisse a onorare i propri debiti, i creditori potrebbero pretendere il pagamento da ogni socio soltanto nei limiti della quota, cioè per 2.000 euro.

Esempio: Il signor Giovanni Verdi costituisce una spa che realizza un utile di 70.000 euro: la tassazione è di 21.980 euro. Se il signor Giovanni Verdi avesse aperto la sua attività con una ditta individuale, la tassazione sarebbe stata di 23.370 euro, con imposte maggiori per 1.390 euro.

Allo stesso tempo, la società di capitali presenta anche alcuni svantaggi:

  • è una forma sconsigliabile per aziende di piccole dimensioni;
  • è un tipo di società costoso;
  • le decisioni devono essere prese con particolari procedure;
  • hai l’obbligo di redigere e depositare un bilancio d’esercizio;
  • la società deve essere gestita in contabilità ordinaria;
  • per costituirla, è necessario un atto costitutivo scritto e redatto da un notaio.

In conclusione, si tratta di una forma giuridica adatta se tu e i tuoi soci volete realizzare medi e grandi investimenti, assumendo anche rischi elevati.

body.value:
The limited liability company

The limited liability company is a type of joint-stock company.

To start up a limited liability company, a written deed registered by a notary public is required. In addition, when the company is set up, paid up share capital of at least 10,000 euros is mandatory.

Together with your partners, you can also choose to pay up only 25% of the share capital, at least at an initial stage.

You can set up a limited liability company also on your own: this form is called a one-man limited liability company (srl unipersonale). Your liability remains limited to the value of your shares in the company. Nonetheless, remember that in this case the initial capital of 10,000 euros must be fully paidup from the very beginning.

Finally, do not forget that your liability becomes unlimited:

  • if you do not pay up the share capital;
  • if you do not follow the proper procedures in notifying the setting up of your company;
  • if your company fails to regularly settle debts when due.

For further information on limited liability companies, please refer to Article 2462 of the Civil Code at this link: www.altalex.com/index.php?idnot=37058.

body.value:
The joint-stock company form provides a number of advantages:

  • you can share your decisions on business activities with other partners;
  • with this form, you can manage medium- and large-sized companies;
  • your liability and that of your partners is limited to the value of the company's share capital;
  • the economic and financial management is more easily controlled;
  • if profits are high, there is an advantage in fiscal terms.

E.g.: suppose that the partners responsible for the Rosso e Nero snc joint-stock company possess, as part of their personal assets, properties worth 200,000 euros, securities worth 80,000 euros, two vehicles worth 50,000 euros and that their company has debts amounting to 50,000 euros; the shares owned by each partner amount to 2,000 euros. If the company is unable to pay its debts, creditors may require payment by each shareholder only up to the value of their shares, i.e. 2,000 euros.

E.g.: Mr. Giovanni Verdi opens a joint-stock company that makes a profit of 70,000 euros: taxes amount to 21,980 euros. If Mr. Verdi had opened his business as a sole proprietorship, the tax value would have been 23,370 euros, with a higher tax of 1,390 euros.

At the same time, the joint-stock company also has some disadvantages:

  • as a corporate form, it is not advisable for small companies;
  • it is an expensive corporate form;
  • decisions mustbe made following special procedures;
  • a yearly balance sheet must be drawn up and submitted;
  • the company must be managed using an ordinary accounting scheme;
  • to set it up, a written company charter drawn up by a notary public is required.

In conclusion, this is an appropriate legal form if you and your partners wish to make high-risk medium to large investments.

items.title: Why choose a joint-stock company: advantages and disadvantages

body.value:
If you and your partners decide to start a company with other partners as a joint-stock corporation, you can carry out commercial activities. In this case, however, the most important decisions for your company need to be taken through special procedures and during dedicated meetings.

You may choose among five options:

  • the limited liability company (srl);
  • the low-capital limited liability company (srlcr);
  • the simplified partnership (ssrl);
  • the joint-stock company (spa);
  • the joint-stock limited partnership (sapa)

You are required to the following:

1. the VAT number to be registered at the Inland Revenue;

2. the registration on the list of national enterprises (Registro delle Imprese);

3. the registration on the INPS (the National Social Security Institute) lists;

If your company is incorporated as an unlimited partnership or a limited partnership, you and your partners get to choose the most appropriate accounting scheme.

body.value:
If your choice falls on a limited partnership, you and your associates will have the opportunity to decide who among you wishes to take care of company management and who instead wishes to be a partner without assuming the risks and the liability of business decisions.

In a limited partnership, partners are divided into limited partners and unlimited partners: this means that only the unlimited partners can make decisions concerning the activity of the company.

Furthermore, all unlimited members have unlimited joint and several liability while the limited partners participate only economically by providing the company with funds.

E.g.: a limited partnership includes two partners: Yellow and Blue. Yellow has a 500 euro share and is an unlimited partner; Blue has a 300 euro share and is a limited partner. If the company has debts amounting to 10,000 euros, Blue may be required to pay only 300 euros of the debt.

Just as for an snc company, a written company charter is needed.

For further information on the functioning of limited partnerships, please refer to the link www.altalex.com/index.php?idnot=37055, where detailed information on Article 2313 of the Italian Civil Code is provided.

body.value:
Being a partnership facilitates carrying on business activities with several advantages, because:

  • you can share your decisions on business activities with other partners without needing special procedures;
  • you can set up your company without paying up any capital sum;
  • with this form, you can manage small and medium-sized companies;
  • within certain limits, you are not required to draw up and submit a yearly balance sheet;
  • to some extent, bookkeeping can be performed based on a simplified scheme.

At the same time, a partnership also has some disadvantages:

  • as a business entity, it is not advisable for large companies;
  • if you set up a partnership, your responsibility and that of your partners in terms of company debts is joint, several and unlimited;
  • if you set up a partnership, your responsibility and that of your partners in terms of company debts is joint, several and unlimited.

E.g.: suppose that the partners responsible for the Blu snc partnership possess, as part of their personal assets, a property worth 300,000 euros, securities worth 10,000 euros, two vehicles worth 60,000 euros and that their company has debts amounting to 50,000 euros. If the company is unable to pay its debts, acquisition of the securities would be enough to settle the debt.

In conclusion, this is an appropriate legal form if you and your partners wish to make low-risk small and medium investments.

body.value:
The simple partnership allows carrying out business activities with several advantages, because:

  • you can share your decisions on business activities with other partners without needing special procedures;
  • you can set up your company without depositing any capital or registering any deed;
  • its management does not imply high costs;
  • you are not required to draw up and submit a yearly balance sheet;
  • it is the ideal form for farms and estate management;
  • bookkeeping and the related formalities are much easier.

At the same time, the simple partnership also entails some disadvantages:

  • you cannot perform commercial activities;
  • your responsibility and that of your partners in terms of company debts is personal and unlimited.

E.g.: suppose that the partners of the Green Garden simple partnership possess, as part of their personal assets, properties worth 500,000 euros, a car worth 15,000 euros, a piece of land worth 100,000 euros and that their company has debts amounting to 600,000 euros. If the company cannot not pay its debts, creditors may retaliate on the property and on the land owned by the individual members.

In a nutshell, this is an appropriate legal form if you and your partners wish to make small investments and assume low risks, especially in the field of agriculture and estate management.

body.value:
If you wish to start an activity as a farmer, you can take advantage of specific benefits: both if you wish to work on your own or in partnership with other people.

It is a special scheme designed and enacted for this specific category.

To qualify, you must:

  • be a farmer, pursuant to Article 2135 of the Italian Civil Code;
  • sell your produce.

You can also sell the produce of others, but not as the main activity.

Further information on agricultural and fishery-related entrepreneurship is available in Article 2135 of the Italian Civil Code at the following link: www.altalex.com/index.php?idnot=36498.

By entering this system, you can pay the Value Added Tax (IVA) on a flat-rate basis, instead of having to comply with the regulations that apply to other forms of business.

E.g.: Let us see an example of a flat-rate scheme application. Suppose that an agricultural company sells vegetables to the amount of 5,000 euros. The VAT to be applied on this sum is 10%, amounting to 500 euros. An additional 4% rate is calculated on this amount (called compensation rate). The calculated amount of this is 200 euros and is subtracted from the previous 500: the VAT to be paid to the State is 300 euros.

In any case, nothing prevents you from adopting the ordinary VAT scheme.

Moreover, if during the year your business has achieved a turnover not exceeding 7,000 euros, you may decide not to pay VAT and you are not required to comply with the ordinary accounting and tax requirements.

You will be required simply to number and keep the documents of purchases and sales.

Keep in mind that the term "farmer" also refers to entrepreneurs carrying out business activities in the fishing sector, including freshwater, mussel, oyster and other shellfish farming.

Further information on the flat-rate scheme is available in Article 34 of Presidential Decree 633/72 (Testo IVA): www3.unisi.it/ammin/uff-ragi/Fisco/DPR633-72.htm.

The minimum taxpayer scheme (also referred to as "regime di vantaggio per le nuove attività") is a simplification to promote new businesses.

If you wish to set up your company as a sole proprietorship, this scheme may be suitable for you.
